block.p: Heightened NATO Air Raids Aim to Weaken Milosevic NATO opened an expanded bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, and alliance officials said they were planning weeks of air strikes intended to undermine President Slobodan Milosevic's hold on power.
Three American infantrymen patrolling Macedonia's border with Kosovo were missing after reporting by radio that they were surrounded and under fire, the Pentagon said.

Heightened NATO Air Raids Aim to Weaken Milosevic NATO opened an expanded bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, and alliance officials said they were planning weeks of air strikes intended to undermine President Slobodan Milosevic's hold on power.
Three American infantrymen patrolling Macedonia's border with Kosovo were missing after reporting by radio that they were surrounded and under fire, the Pentagon said.
NATO adopted a strategy of bombing Yugoslavia despite several military assessments and intelligence warnings that it alone would not deter attacks in Kosovo.
France will provide 10 airplanes to protect Kosovo refugee convoys from Serbian forces, and Italy will send police officers to Albania to bring order to refugee camps.
Russia said it would send a reconnaissance ship to the Mediterranean to monitor the conflict in Yugoslavia, a move criticized by the United States as unhelpful.
Serbian forces are shelling villages, towns and cities across a wide swath of Kosovo, refugees said.
Computer users in Serbia managed to temporarily disable NATO's Web site last weekend and to cause intermittent outages over the last few days, NATO officials said.

The international war crimes tribunal disclosed that it had warned Yugoslav officials that they would be accountable for violence against civilians in Kosovo. It also said it had indicted Zeljiko Raznatovic, the Serbian militia leader known as Arkan.
Two Kosovo Albanian leaders reported to have been summarily executed by Serbs were now said to be alive.

Zambia Founder is Stateless The Zambian High Court has ruled that Kenneth D. Kaunda, the father of modern Zambia and the country's President for 27 years, is not a Zambian citizen under the Constitution because his parents were from the former British Nyasaland, now called Malawi.

Ulster Deal Remains Elusive Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland continued to press Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders to compromise in the dispute over the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army.

U.S. Drug Chief Open To Farmers Growing Hemp Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, director of the White House's Office of National Drug Control Policy, indicated in an interview that his opposition to the growing of hemp in the United States was softening. Hemp is a nonintoxicating look-alike cousin of marijuana that is grown for fiber, seed and oil. It is banned in the war on drugs, but some American wheat farmers are seeking the right to grow it. Legislation to revive hemp has passed in Hawaii and been introduced in at least five other state legislatures.

Minister Sentenced to Prison A Florida judge sentenced the Rev. Henry Lyons, 57, to more than five years in prison for swindling more than $4 million while he was president of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A., the largest black religious group in the country.

Court Backs I.R.S. on Church A Federal court has upheld an I.R.S. decision to revoke a New York church's tax-exempt status for taking out newspaper advertisements before the 1992 Presidential election that strongly suggested Christians not vote for Bill Clinton.

U.S. Reports 2000 Progress The White House said 92 percent of the Federal Government's essential computer systems were ready for the year 2000, but predicted that Americans would have difficulty reaching some foreign countries by telephone or airplane after Jan. 1 because some computers overseas would not be fixed in time.

Assessment of Climate Treaty The United States and other industrial countries may find it easier and cheaper than expected to comply with a proposed treaty to fight global warming, largely because of reduced fuel consumption in Russia, a Government agency said.

Court Hears Federalism Case The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether state employees could go to state court to sue for federally guaranteed overtime pay. It was the first of four arguments in important Federalism cases.

Redefining 'Blue Moon' Sky and Telescope magazine has discovered that the modern definition of a blue moon -- as the second full moon in a month, something 1999 has had twice -- is based upon an error that the magazine made in 1946.

4 Officers Are Arraigned In Bronx on Murder Charges The four New York City police officers in the Amadou Diallo killing were arraigned on two counts of second-degree murder each and were suspended from the force. Each count is punishable by a maximum of 25 years to life in prison. The officers also face one charge of reckless endangerment in the first degree. They all pleaded not guilty and were released on $100,000 bail each. Hundreds of demonstrators on both sides of the case gathered outside the Bronx courthouse.
Mayor Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir, attending a ceremony honoring a slain officer, made impassioned speeches urging greater respect for the police.
Ex-Union Officials Indicted Connie Lango and Francine Autovino, former officials of a District Council 37 local for City University clerical workers, were indicted on embezzlement charges.
High-Tech Hospital Checkout An increasing number of hospitals are using technology like data chips and scannable bracelets to make sure the right baby goes home with the right parents.

An Owner Maybe, Not a Player The Charlotte Hornets and the agent for Michael Jordan denied that the former N.B.A. star would come out of retirement to play for the Hornets. Jordan is considering buying a 50 percent stake in the team.

Max Mandell The founder of Mandell Nursery School and Kindergarten on the Upper West Side was 90. Mr. Mandell had acknowledged that he devoted his life to making up for his mother's rejection by passing on a grandfather's love to generations of young children.
Yahoo-Broadcast.com Deal Yahoo was said to be ready to announce today that it had agreed to buy Broadcast.com in a stock swap valued at $5.6 billion.
Profits Trail Economy's Growth After-tax corporate profits in the fourth quarter fell 1 percent from the previous quarter, even as the economy raced out of 1998.

A Lengthy Antitrust Trial The presiding judge in the Microsoft antitrust case set May 10 as the tentative date for the trial to resume and laid out a longer timetable for additional testimony, oral arguments and written submissions, virtually insuring that the trial would not end much before 2000.
Further Retreat From 10,000 The Dow fell 127.10 points, to 9,786.16; the S.& P. 500 dropped 14.38, to 1,300.75, and the Nasdaq lost 18.89, to 2,461.40.
Discontent Denied The co-chairmen of DaimlerChrysler responded angrily to reports of managerial troubles.
New Publisher for GQ Thomas A. Florio, the publisher of Conde Nast Traveler and the former publisher of The New Yorker, was named publisher of GQ.
